Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evidence-based Pedagogy in Engineering Education: Design Heuristics for Concept Generation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The engineering design ability is critical in all undergraduate engineering programs. Design fixation is one of the common problems facing engineering design teams. This project is creating and evaluating tools that will help the design group avoid the design fixation problem. The work is taking a unique approach to the problem by creating 77 heuristics to help design groups avoid the fixation problem.

The technique is based on prior studies involving both student and professional teams. This prior work has demonstrated the technique is applicable to both design groups. The prior success provides a high level of confidence that this work will be successful.

Because design is included in all engineering programs and because the design heuristics are rather generic the work pre performed in this project is applicable to virtually all engineering programs nationally. As a result a successful result in this project could be a transformative innovation for engineering education.

This project is also producing instructional workshops to help instructors utilize the heuristics to enhance creativity in design courses. The workshops are not single point in time delivery of information but are distributed throughout time providing a long-term engagement of faculty. This type of prolonged engagement has proven to be more effective than other means of development and will produce excellent long term change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To face the Grand Challenges in Engineering of the 21st Century, our workforce must be capable of innovation; however, students and practitioners across disciplines often face unstructured, ambiguous design problems without strategies in hand to assist them. Even experienced designers fall into the same trap: while the first new idea may come easily, it is often difficult to generate more,  especially ideas that are different from one another. As a result, designers often become “fixated,” limiting their consideration of alternatives. To help engineering students and practitioners alike learn ways to generate innovative ideas, we developed and tested a cognitive tool called, “Design Heuristics.” Design Heuristics are a collection of empirically-derived strategies that support the engineer in generating and developing more and different ideas. Based on studies of the “best practices” of product designers, Design Heuristics provide even novice students with a “jump start” into successful idea generation.

 

The research project was aimed at testing the efficacy of Design Heuristics in idea generation and development, developing curricula for teaching Design Heuristics in varied engineering education settings, and promulgating its use in the fields of engineering and design. Our project created a series of four instructional lessons focused on concept generation: (1) idea initiation, (2) idea development, (3) subcomponent design, and (4) team ideation. These lessons were designed to fit within existing undergraduate engineering courses to support instruction on idea generation for any design project. The four lessons were then examined in instructional settings with engineering students at varying levels of education.

 

These lessons provide students with a comprehensive understanding of how and when to use Design Heuristics in engineering projects, and are suitable for students from a wide range of design backgrounds. Using Design Heuristics to initiate ideas resulted in students’ improved ability to generate more concepts to consider, supporting their creative efforts past the point of exhaustion. Working with Design Heuristics, students also successfully transformed their existing designs into further explorations of possible concepts, resulting in variations to achieve desired functions, improve aesthetics, and simplify usability. The subcomponent design lesson used Design Heuristics within morphological segments that allowed students to address key functions by elaborating on features and considering additional context as compared to their initial ideas.  Finally, the team ideation lesson found that Design Heuristics can foster interactions with teammates through shared and differing perspectives on the design process. Results from across our studies demonstrated that engineering students benefit from instruction on Design Heuristics as measured by their outcomes: more unique, diverse, elaborate, and practical ideas.

 

Our project also focused on promulgating these lessons through a wide range of engineering education settings. To support the uptake of these lessons by instructors across the country, we offered workshops at research, professional education, and K-12 educational conferences in the U.S. We engaged over 100 instructors in national workshops (ASEE, IDETC, Learn by Design, and ICED), and from these workshops invited participants to lead local workshops with our support at their home institutions. We supported 12 instructors in leading local workshops with over 70 additional instructors. We studied the integration of the Design Heuristics into existing courses and found that instructors felt the integration was relatively easy and that students benefitted from the pedagogy. Across the nation, instructors introduced the tool in courses for high school students, freshmen through seniors, and graduate students, and facilitated their students in using the tool for idea initiation and idea development, including 37 different universities and 68 different locations. We also provided these lessons for online learning in five modules within the NSF-sponsored C2GEN program (http://www.c2gen.org).

 

Arguably, the most important goal of STEM education for innovation is how to create new ideas. The impact of this project centers on its contributions to design methods in engineering education. The systematic growth and refinement of the Design Heuristics Pedagogy demonstrates how engineering educators at all levels, and in varied institutions, can incorporate these lessons within their existing curricula. Our pedagogy on idea generation in engineering design provides a method to help students generate novel, original concepts, and to become skilled and confident while doing so. This project allows engineering students to “leave their mark” on their work by contributing ideas no one else has previously offered. This personal engagement in the engineering process may have even greater impact for students who see themselves as offering important differences to the engineering corps. As a result, our project on idea generation pedagogy using Design Heuristics has broader impact by informing engineering students about the importance of differences in ideas leading to innovation.
